questions.question_text:
A user has launched an EC2 instance store backed instance in the US-East-1a zone. The user created AMI #1 and copied it to the Europe region. After that, the user made a few updates to the application running in the US-East-1a zone. The user makes an AMI#2 after the changes. If the user launches a new instance in
Europe from the AMI #1 copy, which of the below mentioned statements is true?

choices.D: The new instance in the EU region will not have the changes made after the AMI copy
choices.B: The new instance will have the changes made after the AMI copy since AWS keeps updating the AMI
choices.C: It is not possible to copy the instance store backed AMI from one region to another
choices.A: The new instance will have the changes made after the AMI copy as AWS just copies the reference of the original AMI during the copying. Thus, the copied AMI will have all the updated data

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In this scenario, the user created AMI #1 from the instance in the US-East-1a zone and then copied it to the Europe region. However, any changes made to the original instance after the creation of AMI #1 will not be reflected in the copied AMI #1.
D is the correct answer.
Correct Answer: D
D. The new instance in the EU region will not have the changes made after the AMI copy

questions.answer_description: Within EC2, when the user copies an AMI, the new AMI is fully independent of the source AMI; there is no link to the original (source. AMI. The user can modify the source AMI without affecting the new AMI and vice a versa. Therefore, in this case even if the source AMI is modified, the copied AMI of the EU region will not have the changes. Thus, after copy the user needs to copy the new source AMI to the destination region to get those changes.

questions.question_text: A user runs the command `dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/xvdfbs=1M` on a fresh blank EBS volume attached to a Linux instance. Which of the below mentioned activities is the user performing with the command given above?

choices.A: Creating a file system on the EBS volume
choices.B: Mounting the device to the instance

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In the given command dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/xvdf bs=1M, the user is using the dd command to write zeroes (/dev/zero) to the block device (/dev/xvdf) with a block size of 1MB (bs=1M).

Pre-warming an EBS volume involves initializing the volume by reading and writing a significant amount of data to ensure optimal performance before actual use. By using the dd command to write zeroes to the EBS volume, the user is pre-warming the volume.

C
"For volumes that were created from snapshots, the storage blocks must be pulled down from Amazon S3 and written to the volume before you can access them. This preliminary action takes time and can cause a significant increase in the latency of I/O operations the first time each block is accessed. Volume performance is achieved after all blocks have been downloaded and written to the volume. For volumes that have been created from snapshots, use the dd or fio utilities to read from all of the blocks on a volume. All existing data on the volume will be preserved."
Correct Answer: C
C. Pre warming the EBS volume
New EBS volumes receive their maximum performance the moment that they are available and do not require initialization (formerly known as pre-warming).

questions.answer_description:
When the user creates a new EBS volume and is trying to access it for the first time it will encounter reduced IOPS due to wiping or initiating of the block storage.
To avoid this as well as achieve the best performance it is required to pre warm the EBS volume. For a blank volume attached with a Linux OS, the ג€ddג€ command is used to write to all the blocks on the device. In the command ג€dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/xvdfbs=1Mג€ the parameter ג€if =import fileג€ should be set to one of the
Linux virtual devices, such as /dev/zero. The ג€of=output fileג€ parameter should be set to the drive that the user wishes to warm. The ג€bsג€ parameter sets the block size of the write operation; for optimal performance, this should be set to 1 MB.

questions.answer_description:
CloudWatch is used to monitor AWS as well as the custom services. It provides either basic or detailed monitoring for the supported AWS products. In basic monitoring, a service sends data points to CloudWatch every five minutes, while in detailed monitoring a service sends data points to CloudWatch every minute.
To enable detailed instance monitoring for a new Auto Scaling group, the user does not need to take any extra steps. When the user creates an Auto Scaling launch config as the first step for creating an Auto Scaling group, each launch configuration contains a flag named InstanceMonitoring.Enabled. The default value of this flag is true. Thus, the user does not need to set this flag if he wants detailed monitoring.

choices.B: By default detailed monitoring is enabled for Auto Scaling
choices.D: Enable detail monitoring from the AWS console
choices.C: Auto Scaling does not support detailed monitoring
choices.A: When the user sets an alarm on the Auto Scaling group, it automatically enables detail monitoring

questions.question_text: A user has created a VPC with a public subnet. The user has terminated all the instances which are part of the subnet. Which of the below mentioned statements is true with respect to this scenario?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When instances are terminated within a subnet, their associated network interfaces are also terminated. Network interfaces are created for instances and are linked to the instance's lifecycle. So, when the instances are terminated, their network interfaces are automatically deleted as well.

comments.content: EIPs won't be deleted by default but I do not see a better option.

discussion.content: B. All network interface attached with the instances will be deleted

When an instance is launched it will have a network interface attached with it. The user cannot delete the subnet until he terminates the instance and deletes the network interface. When the user terminates the instance all the network interfaces attached with it are also deleted.

choices.D: The subnet to which the instances were launched with will be deleted
choices.C: When the user launches a new instance it cannot use the same subnet
